channel.title: ElevenRoute
channel.description: Anatoliy Yastreb's travel blog. I write here about all the places I visit and share my experiences.

item.title: Phi Phi Islands, Thailand
item.description:
Not far away from Phuket, where we settled, located Phi Phi islands. That's where we went for a boat trip with a company called Offspray Leisure, they've got best reviews on the Internet.
The trip takes about 6-7 hours on a speed boat. Together with us there were about 15 other people, mostly americans :smile:
Maya Bay has a famous beach, where movie "The Beach" with Di Caprio was filmed. This beach is in fact so famous, that it was too overcrowded. Our guide decided not to stop there and to go further.
For lunch we stopped at a small wild beach where a picnic was set up for us. In the bay of this beach there were tiny baby reef-sharks swimming. Our captain assured everybody that they don't bite people and decided to feed them with some leftovers from the picnic :smile:

After lunch we visited Vikings Caves where a chinese company harvests swallows' nests to make very expensive soup.

Our next stop should have been Monkey Island. It's actually just a bay at the north of the island where lots of monkeys live. But due to low tide our boat was unable to come close to the beach and it was way overcrowded as well, so we just watched the monkeys from far away and went further.
Our last stop was snorkeling at Ko Mai Thon island, not far away from Phuket.
We enjoyed the trip and would definitely recommend to visit Phi-Phi!

item.title: Copenhagen, Denmark
item.description:
We arrived in Copenhagen at Christmas. The weather was good on our arrival, but it changes here several times per day :smile:
In the morning it could be sunny, then rain for half an hour and a hail storm in the evening. And after that clear starry sky in the night.

After the events in Berlin there are concrete barriers and police on the streets.

Copenhagen - the birthplace of Tuborg.

Swedish Church.

Frederik's Church, also known as the Marble Church.

Guards.

Copenhagen Opera House - one of the newest and most expensive opera houses in the world. Its construction cost of 500 million dollars.

New Harbour.

Bicycle-pedestrian bridge.

The Royal Danish Theatre.

Residential complex on the waterfront.

Church of the Savior.

Circular bridge resembles a ship.

Christiansborg Palace.

Town Hall Square.

The weather began to deteriorate.

Rosenborg Palace Garden.

Rosenborg Palace, Danish kings have lived here.

Not far from the palace is the area called Nyubuder, Royal Danish Navy were housed here in the 17th century.

By evening, I decided to walk to the main attractions - the Mermaid. There were a lot of people, all trying to make a selfie with mermaid and almost jumping into the water.

As soon as I walked away from the mermaid a hail storm started.

The main purpose of our trip was to visit the meditation course in one of the first centers of the Karma Kagyu Buddhist school in the western world. The center was founded in 1972. The center is located in a historic residential district of Copenhagen.

The most beautiful gompa (meditation room) in a traditional style.

Painting are done according to the rules of Buddhist painting.

item.title: Tenerife, Spain
item.description:
Tenerife is one of the Canarian Islands, the highest peak of Spain - Teide volcano is located here. Firstly we came here for one month but later decided to stay for two :smile:
We rented an apartment with an ocean view in a small town called Puerto de Santiago near to Los Gigantos. West coast of the island has less rainfalls in the autumn and is less windy than south coast.
As it turned out, the high season on Tenerife starts in November and accommodation prices grow almost twice!

Rocky beach near to one of the hotels, we've snorkled here for a bit.

There is an ocean water pool nearby. Actually, it's just a chunk of ocean surrounded by concrete walls.

Sunset view from our balcony.

Went for a ride to Teide volcano. The road there goes through a national park.
Another attraction nearby was whale & dolphin watching boat trip. We chose a boat called "Flipper Uno", the trip is 2 hours long and cost 20 EUR. The price includes paella on board and drinks from the bar.
We couldn't find any whales, but spotted a few dolphins. They were swimming near the boat and jumping out of the water.

Masca canyon, another popular tourist attraction.

We met another sunset in the evening.

On the next day we went to Masca village. This small village became popular once the road there was built. The hike down to Masca canyon starts in this village.
There is an option to order a trip where you will be taken to the village by bus/taxi. From the village you hike down to the ocean, where a boat will be waiting to take you back to Los Gigantos.
We decided to go with our own car without a booked trip, just to visit the village. The road there is very narrow and windy and sometimes it gets scary :smile: The village itself did not impress us very much.

There is snow already on top of the Teide.

Another sunset, this time with rain.

Near to the capital of the island, Santa-Cruz-de-Tenerife, there is one interesting beach - Playa de Las Teresitas. It is about 1.3 km long and the sand was brought here from the Sahara desert by barges.
Most of the beaches on the island have black volcanic sand.
After the beach we visited the capital city - Santa-Cruz-de-Tenerife. Central square is a big shallow pool which gets filled by water from time to time.

Tourist information in a hobbit-house.

Looks like this building has only one wall. But it's actually triangular.

Visited Garcia Sanabria park.

There is a whole cactus forest in there.

For dinner we went to a place called Santo Pecado. At 7 PM all the restaurants were almost empty. 7 PM is too early for locals, they start their dinner at around 9 PM.

Grilled salmon roll

Croquettes

Vegetable Curry

Santo Pecado Burger

Tenerife is a great place to spend winter, by the end of November it got a bit colder and windy, but still very comfortable place :smile:

item.title: Warsaw, Poland
item.description:
We stayed in Warsaw for 4 days and rented an apartment not far away from central train station, in the skyscrapers district. Around Stalin's high-rising building they've built a lot of modern skyscrapers and malls.

Portable monuments to war heroes.

Walked around the old city - a small piece of historical settlement.

Central market square and mermaid statue - a symbol of Warsaw.

Guard of honor at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

Went for a walk at the Visla river bank. There was some kind of a street-food festival.

National Stadium used for soccer matches.

On the next day we visited Lazienki Park, the largest park in Warsaw, occupying 76 hectares of the city center. There we saw a deer and a squirrel.

item.title: Munich, Germany
item.description:
We stayed in Munich for a couple of days at our friends, who moved there from Dsseldorf. First thing we visited was Olympic park and BMW museum. We didn't go inside the museum, just visited free exhibition around it.

Electric car is charging from solar power. Future is here.

After museum we went on top of the tower in the Olympic park. There is an open observation deck without windows or nets from where you can see entire city. Munich doesn't have much high rise buildings, but has a lot of parks.

Olympic village where sportsmen lived in the 1972 Olympic Games.

BMW museum and factory.

For lunch we went to a restaurant nearby the main train station.

Mostly traditional German food.

After lunch we went for a walk around the old city. There was nothing surprising here in Munich - as in other european cities there is a City Hall and a few churches. Many buildings were closed for renovation.
On our way back home we walked near the river. There were a lot of people on the beach sunbathing and grilling.

item.title: Salzburg, Austria
item.description:
We bought our tickets on the bus company website FlixBus, arrived to the train stations (usually buses also depart from train station or from nearby), and waited for our bus. But it didn't come because as it turned out we've bought train tickets :smile: We had to buy new tickets and wait 2 more hours for the next train.
We arrived in Salzburg at the evening. We didn't have much time so we just went for a short walk in the city center.

Interesting factory building.

Salzburg is the birthplace of Mozart, everything here has a music theme.

On the main street we met street musicians playing classical music. They were quite good :smile:

House where Mozart was born.

On the Mozartplatz we met another street band called StreetWhispers. They are playign very good jazz, so good that one lady couldn't hold it and started to dance :smile:

The smallest house in Austria.

The whole shop of Mozartkugeln candies.

item.title: Vienna, Austria
item.description:
From Budapest to Vienna we got by BlaBlaCar. Our driver turned out to be a ukrainian, driving from western Ukraine to Vienna :smile: Our drive was fast and uneventful and we've settled in our apartment once we got there. Like in Zurich, our apartment had automated check-in - there was a safe near to the apartment, and the agency had emailed us a password for the safe a day before. Inside the safe was the key for apartment - and no need to wait for anybody :smile:
Our apartment was not far away from amusement park called Prater. The giant ferris wheel, called Riesenrad, was built in 1896. There are lots of attractions, contests and other activities in this park.
On the next day we went to the city center. We started from the City Hall and Rathausplatz. On the days we were in Vienna there was some kind of cinema festival, and there was a giant screen and seats for the free screenings.

From the City Hall we went to Austrian Parliament.

And then to Folksgarten.

Strange sculpture.

There are a lot of free drinking water stands in Vienna - quite handy in the hot weather.

The only modern building in Vienna old city center - Haas House. It is considered controversial, some people like it, another hate it :smile:

Also we walked in the city park - Stadtpark. Here, as well as in other parks in Vienna, are a lot of benches.

Vienna Opera. Unfortunately the season was over in August and we didn't get in.

Close to the Opera there is Hotel Sacher, in its cafe they serve original Sacher Cake.

And of course the journey wouldn't be complete without a visit to a local city market :smile: We went to the Naschmarkt not far away from the Opera. It's the biggest market in Vienna. The market was here since XVIII century.

For lunch we went to the mediterranean cafe - falafel, humus and pita.

Interesting sign.

There is also a monument to soviet soldiers in Vienna.

And lastly we went to the park of Belveder - Belvederegarten. Belvedere Palace was built as a summer residency of prince Eugene of Savoy's.

There was a heron on the sculpture.

Around the palace was some exhibitions of statues from Chinese horoscope - Dog, Horse, Dragon, etc.

And the concrete Snowman.

item.title: Budapest, Hungary
item.description:
Budapest was on our list for a long time and just happen to be on the way from Ukraine to Germany. You can get here from Kyiv by WizzAir - tickets usually cost around 50-60 EUR, but we bought ours in advance and they were just 25 EUR per person.
We arrived in Budapest early in the morning and check-in in our rented apartment was only after 14:00, so we had to wait in a cafe nearby. We also had lunch there :smile:
After settling in and a short rest we went for an evening walk on the river bank. Our apartment was almost in the city center right in front of the river.

We lived in the yellow building on the right side.

Chain bridge, it was opened in 1849 and became first permanent bridge across Danube river.

Hungarian Parliament.

On the next day it was raining in the morning. As usual, we decided to go to local city market, it was close to our place. There everything was without surprises. There are two levels in the market. On the first level they sell fruits, vegetables and meat. And on the second level there are some clothing shops and cafes. Also, there is a German discounter supermarket Aldi in the basement of the market building.

Dohny Street Synagogue - it's the largest synagogue in Europe.

Budapest Opera.

Memorial to Soviet heroes who liberated Budapest in World War II.

Shoes on the Danube Bank - memorial created to honor Jews who were killed in World War II.

On the next day the weather was better and we went for a walk again.

Went by the market.

Local trolleybus called "Ikarus". In Ukraine we have the same, but as a regular bus :smile:

For a lunch we went to a vegan cafe.

Zero kilometer - from this point the distance to other cities in Hungary is calculated.

Fisherman's Bastion is an architectural complex on the Castle hill in Buda part of the city.

item.title: Cannes, France
item.description:
From Nice we moved to Cannes, it's just half an hour train ride. We arrived in Cannes one day before the start of the film festival. The preparations for the main event of the year were going on everywhere. We didn't make it to the festival because our flight was on the next day and regular people are not allowed there anyway, it is only for film industry professionals.

Photographers are taking places.

The harbor is filled up with huge yachts, on many of them will be parties with celebrities. In Cannes you feel yourself like a beggar, not at ease So many posh and expensive stuff around, but regular people are not invited.

Screens are set up on the beach where films from the festival will be played.

Modern art.

On the next day morning we went to a local open market - March Forville. Here everything is as usual at european city markets - fruits, vegetables and some cooked food.

Some very good quiche pies and desserts were sold here.

Popular french dish - fried zucchini blossoms.

After the market we walked around the city for a bit more and went to Marseille, from where we had a flight to Spain.

Near Martinez Hotel crowds of fans are waiting for celebrities arrival.

item.title: Monaco
item.description:
Monaco is located in only half an hour train ride away from Nice, so we decided to visit it. Monaco is a tiny state, its territory is only 2.02 km2.
We didn't have much time because we had to go to Cannes in the evening, so we spent only 2 hours here. We took a ride on the bus, walked around the Oceanographic Museum and went back to Nice.
